notes:
1. Traffic Flow Parameters

Traffic flow is described by three fundamental macroscopic parameters:

  • Flow Rate ($q$): Also called Volume. The number of vehicles passing a point per unit time (usually vehicles per hour, vph).
  • Speed ($u$): The distance traveled per unit time. Space Mean Speed ($u_s$) is the harmonic mean of individual vehicle speeds and is used in flow theory relationships.
  • Density ($k$): The number of vehicles occupying a given length of roadway (usually vehicles per mile, vpm, or vehicles per km).

2. The Fundamental Relationship

These three parameters are related by the fundamental equation of traffic flow:

$$ q = k \cdot u_s $$

Flow Rate = Density $\times$ Space Mean Speed

3. Greenshields Model

The simplest model relating speed and density is the Greenshields model, which assumes a linear relationship:

$$ u_s = u_f \left( 1 - \frac{k}{k_j} \right) $$
  • $u_f$: Free-flow speed (speed when density is zero).
  • $k_j$: Jam density (density when speed is zero, i.e., traffic is stopped).

Substituting this into the fundamental equation gives a parabolic relationship between flow and density:

$$ q = u_f k - \frac{u_f}{k_j} k^2 $$

Maximum flow (Capacity, $q_{max}$) occurs at optimal density ($k_{opt} = k_j/2$) and optimal speed ($u_{opt} = u_f/2$).

$$ q_{max} = \frac{u_f k_j}{4} $$

solvedExamples.question: The fundamental relationship of traffic flow relates flow rate (q), density (k), and speed (u). Which equation represents this relationship?
solvedExamples.explanation: The fundamental equation is Flow = Density x Speed ($q = ku$). Think of the units: (veh/hr) = (veh/mi) x (mi/hr).

solvedExamples.question: According to the Greenshields model, maximum flow (capacity) occurs when the speed is:
solvedExamples.explanation: The flow-density curve is a parabola opening downward. The peak of this parabola (maximum flow) occurs at the vertex, which corresponds to half the jam density and half the free-flow speed.

solvedExamples.question: A highway section has a free-flow speed of 60 mph and a jam density of 120 vehicles/mile. What is the maximum flow rate (capacity) predicted by the Greenshields model?
solvedExamples.explanation: Using the formula derived from the Greenshields model: $q_{max} = (u_f \cdot k_j) / 4 = (60 \cdot 120) / 4 = 7200 / 4 = 1800$ vehicles per hour.
